articles.headline: Chávez Dies, Leaving Sharp Divisions in Venezuela
articles.snippet: President Hugo Chávez left behind a nation in the grip of political turmoil that grew more acute as he languished for weeks.
articles.abstract: President Hugo Chávez left behind a nation in the grip of political turmoil that grew more acute as he languished for weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela died Tuesday afternoon after a struggle with cancer, the government announced, leaving behind a bitterly divided nation in the grip of a political crisis that grew more acute as he languished for weeks, silent and out of sight, in hospitals in Havana and Caracas.

articles.headline: Martha Stewart Back in Court in Contract Dispute
articles.snippet: Testifying in a lawsuit by Macy’s over where her branded products can be sold, Ms. Stewart talked about her designs, her past ventures and her prison time.
articles.abstract: Testifying in a lawsuit by Macy’s over where her branded products can be sold, Ms. Stewart talked about her designs, her past ventures and her prison time.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a familiar scene for Martha Stewart’s day in court: photographers camped at the back and front entrances of a Manhattan courthouse, members of the news media lining up for seats, spectators buzzing about what she might say.

articles.headline: The Payoff in Delaying Retirement
articles.snippet: One way of dealing with the federal deadlock is to have older, healthy Americans work a little longer.
articles.abstract: One way of dealing with the federal deadlock is to have older, healthy Americans work a little longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s remarkably difficult to find an economist who thinks the spending cuts ripping through the budget since last Friday amount to a good idea.

articles.headline: U.S. Catholics in Poll See a Church Out of Touch
articles.snippet: In a New York Times/CBS News poll, Catholics said that while their parish priests were in touch with their needs, the church and most American bishops were not.
articles.abstract: In a New York Times/CBS News poll, Catholics said that while their parish priests were in touch with their needs, the church and most American bishops were not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Roman Catholics in the United States say that their church and bishops are out of touch, and that the next pope should lead the church in a more modern direction on issues like birth control and ordaining women and married men as priests, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Dow Companies See an Uneven Recovery
articles.snippet: Some of the 30 companies in the Dow Jones industrial average are still down from their peaks, reflecting a move in financial power.
articles.abstract: Some of the 30 companies in the Dow Jones industrial average are still down from their peaks, reflecting a move in financial power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Behind the bull market that drove the Dow Jones industrial average to a record high on Tuesday is a startling gulf in the fortunes of some of the nation’s largest corporations.

articles.headline: Yahoo Says New Policy Is Meant to Raise Morale
articles.snippet: The abolishment of Yahoo’s work-from-home policy created a stir among workers, but some employees say a new office culture is needed.
articles.abstract: The abolishment of Yahoo’s work-from-home policy created a stir among workers, but some employees say a new office culture is needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Marissa Mayer took over as chief executive at Yahoo last summer, she confronted a Silicon Valley campus that was very different from the one she had left at Google.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: South Africans Seek Meaning in a Shooting
articles.snippet: Reeva Steenkamp, who was shot by the sprinter Oscar Pistorius, had big plans for her newfound fame, including speaking about violence against women in South Africa, friends and family said.
articles.abstract: Reeva Steenkamp, who was shot by the sprinter Oscar Pistorius, had big plans for her newfound fame, including speaking about violence against women in South Africa, friends and family said.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The day before Reeva Steenkamp died, she was getting ready to give a speech on a subject that she had known first hand and that is endemic in South Africa: violence against women.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Lydia Polgreen

articles.headline: Investors’ Quandary: Get In Now?
articles.snippet: As the Dow set a record, investors were weighing whether the market has spent its momentum or is about to reach new heights.
articles.abstract: As the Dow set a record, investors were weighing whether the market has spent its momentum or is about to reach new heights.
articles.lead_paragraph: So is it too late for investors to join the party?

articles.headline: Anger and Kudos as Florida Governor Tacks Left
articles.snippet: Gov. Rick Scott, who recently endorsed a Medicaid expansion, said he had not changed so much as Florida’s economy and deficit changed, freeing him to spend money.
articles.abstract: Gov. Rick Scott, who recently endorsed a Medicaid expansion, said he had not changed so much as Florida’s economy and deficit changed, freeing him to spend money.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A few days after Gov. Rick Scott of Florida endorsed a Medicaid expansion, a U-turn so sharply executed that it flabbergasted his supporters, the head of a local Tea Party group typed up a “breakup note.”

articles.headline: News Corp. Has a Tablet for Schools
articles.snippet: The Amplify, a 10-inch Android tablet for kindergartners through 12th graders, will come with the company’s education curriculum, which can also be used on other devices.
articles.abstract: The Amplify, a 10-inch Android tablet for kindergartners through 12th graders, will come with the company’s education curriculum, which can also be used on other devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two years, Joel I. Klein helped Rupert Murdoch and News Corporation weather a phone-hacking scandal at the company’s British tabloids with the promise that he would eventually be able to return to the role the company hired him for: to spearhead News Corporation’s new venture into the public school market. That day has finally come.
